Title: Health and environmental implications of low-carbon, climate-change resilient diets in India
Description: This project aims to gain a better understanding of what people are eating throughout India, and how this impacts their health and environment.
Institutional Affiliation(s): London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine, the University of Aberdeen and the Public Health Foundation of India

Title: Sustainable Healthy Urban Environments (SHUE)
Description: The research team are building up a database of a globally-distributed selected sample of cities and their populations with the aim to identify the inter-relationship between city characteristics, their use of energy and other resources, and health-related behaviours and exposures.
Institutional Affiliation(s): London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine, Institite of Public Health, Federal University of Bahia, The Complex Built Environment Systems Group at University College London and The Environmental Research Institute, Delhi

Title: Health impacts of a climate change adaptation strategy to address drinking-water salinity in coastal Bangladesh
Description: This project will assess whether managed aquifer recharge (MAR) is beneficial to health, and whether it will remain effective after expected environmental changes
Individual Affiliation(s): Dr Md Mahbubur Rahman, Dr Abu Mohd Naser Titu, Dr Leanne Unicomb
Institutional Affiliation(s): International Center for Diarrhoeal Disease Research, Emory University, Dhaka University, University College London and Stanford University

Title: Consequences of seasonal movements for infectious diseases in a changing climate
Description: This project is examining what human aggregation means for many infectious diseases, using seasonality as a unique probe.
Institutional Affiliation(s): Princeton University, Harvard School of Public Health and the University of Southampton

Title: Long-term impacts of environmental change on health
Description: Health impacts of the tsunami vary with factors such as age, gender and socioeconomic status. Researchers seek to understand whether children who were in the womb at the time of the disaster – when their mothers were exposed to a great deal of stress – are particularly likely to show poor long-term health outcomes.

Title: Toxic haze in SE Asia killed 100,000, study says
Description: Toxic haze that spread across Southeast Asia from Indonesian forest fires last year caused the deaths of about 100,000 people across the region, according to the first academic study of the health impacts of the smog
